elements.title: Arab Coffeehouse (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Arab Coffeehouse (pictured) depicts Henri Matisse's visit to Tangier, where he saw its locals gaze for hours into fishbowls?

elements.title: Vincent Ialenti (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 2017, Vincent Ialenti became the first anthropologist with a feature article in Physics Today?

elements.title: Philippine consulate general in Honolulu (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the chancery of the Philippine consulate general in Honolulu was bought with donations?

elements.title: student-oriented programming language dialect (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Cornell University's student-oriented programming language dialect was made available to other universities but required a "research grant" payment in exchange?

elements.title: John Giffard (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that John Giffard, of Chillington Hall, was described as "arguably Britain's most aristocratic policeman" in 2004?

elements.title: I Lived on Parker Avenue (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the pro-adoption documentary I Lived on Parker Avenue premiered at the Louisiana Governor's Mansion in 2018 at the invitation of Governor John Bel Edwards?

elements.title: A Costume for Nicholas (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the young protagonist of A Costume for Nicholas has Down syndrome, as does his portrayer?

elements.title: North Coast Radio (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that North Coast Radio went silent after playing the song "In a Silent Way"?
